item.title: Palestinian Voices Absent from U.S.-Run Center Planning Gaza’s Future
item.description: U.S. and Israeli soldiers, foreign diplomats and aid workers are congregated in a warehouse in Israel to talk about the future of Gaza. One key group is missing: Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon, Natan Odenheimer and David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: U.S. military personnel and other officials monitor screens displaying imagery of the Gaza Strip during a media tour of the new Civil-Military Coordination Center in Kiryat Gat, Israel, on Monday.

item.title: Trump Dismisses Journalist’s Murder While Praising Saudi Crown Prince
item.description: Hosting Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, President Trump brushed off the murder of Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents, saying, “Things happen.” Fighter jets and investment deals were on the leaders’ agenda today.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump hosted Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia for a black-tie dinner Tuesday at the White House.

item.title: Where Mao’s Peasants Tilled the Soil, Tourists Now Pay for the View
item.description: Decades ago, a Chinese village became an official symbol of revolutionary “self-reliance.” The slogan hasn’t changed, but nearly everything else has.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Gilles Sabrié
item.media:description: Jia Tianlian tending his tiny plot of land in Dazhai, a village in northern China that Mao Zedong once hailed as a model for the nation. In the background are residential buildings from the “people’s commune” of that era.

item.title: U.S. Military Threat Puts Spotlight on Venezuela’s Allies
item.description: American adversaries are unlikely to help President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela fend off a concerted attack. But they have made toppling him harder.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Russian fighter jet and rocket launchers on display in San Carlos del Meta, Venezuela.

item.title: Tanzania: What to Know About the Post-Election Violence
item.description: Post-election violence has tarnished the country’s reputation for stability, and the crackdown may have backfired on the government, as officials in Washington call for a re-examination of U.S. ties.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters help an injured demonstrator near burning barricades amid clashes in Dar es Salaam on Oct. 29, during Tanzania’s presidential election.

item.title: Chinese Spies Are Using LinkedIn to Target U.K. Lawmakers, MI5 Warns
item.description: Britain’s domestic intelligence agency said China was using headhunters to gather intelligence from lawmakers and parliamentary staff members.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Houses of Parliament in London. Dan Jarvis, the British security minister, described a “covert and calculated attempt” by China to gather intelligence there.

item.title: Ecuador Votes ‘No’ to Hosting U.S. Military Base
item.description: A vote on Sunday rejected the expansion of a foreign military presence. It came as the U.S. military’s campaign in waters near Latin America has been roiling the region.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and José María León Cabrera
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Celebrations after the results of a constitutional referendum in Guayaquil, Ecuador, on Sunday.

item.title: UN Support Propels Trump Gaza Plan, but Road Ahead Is Still Rough
item.description: The Security Council’s backing offered a scaffolding of international legitimacy that will be needed to persuade countries to help see the plans through.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Gaza City on Saturday.

item.title: Australian Man Convicted of Murderer Sues to Challenge Vegemite Ban Behind Bars
item.description: A man facing life behind bars is challenging the state of Victoria’s prison ban on the salty condiment beloved by many Australians. The case drew condemnation from a minister for corrections.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: Australian prison officials banned Vegemite in Victoria State out of concern that its potent taste and smell would prevent drug-sniffing dogs from finding contraband.

item.title: Poland Blames Russian-Backed Ukrainians for Railway Sabotage
item.description: Two devices on a main supply line to Ukraine were intended to derail passing trains but failed, the prime minister said, and the two suspects fled the country.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Anatol Magdziarz
item.media:description: Inspectors at the site of a blast on a railway in Mika, Poland, on Sunday.

item.title: Jeju Air Crash Investigators to Hold Public Hearing as They Face Criticism
item.description: With the cause of the disaster in South Korea still unclear after nearly a year, victims’ families have questioned the credibility and impartiality of the inquiry board.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The wreckage of the Jeju Air passenger jet in Muan, South Korea, in December. The plane had skidded off a runway, hit a wall and exploded into a fireball.

item.title: Zelensky Will Try to Revive Peace Talks With Russia During Turkey Visit
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine says he has new proposals to kick-start negotiations with Russia that have been stalled for months.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Madrid on Tuesday. Efforts to end the war with Russia have reached a stalemate since the summer.

item.title: After Hundreds of Gazans Arrive on Mystery Flights, South Africa Asks How
item.description: A little-known group sold passage to desperate Palestinians who didn’t know their destination, catching the South African government by surprise.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Zimasa Matiwane
item.media:description: A Palestinian man, one of those granted entry to South Africa, with his child at an undisclosed location in Johannesburg, on Friday.

item.title: In Nebraska, Makeovers for Buildings That Don’t Price Out the Locals
item.description: In a struggling area of Lincoln, a program pays for repairs and energy efficiency upgrades in rental buildings. In return, landlords must keep rents affordable.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Arin Yoon
item.media:credit: Arin Yoon for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Freedom Comes to My Mind’: Saving Family Legacy and Land in South Carolina
item.description: Conservation can be tough when a property is passed down informally over generations with no clear title. A growing effort is helping families sort it all out.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Nora Williams
item.media:credit: Nora Willams For The New York Times

item.title: Driving an E.V. Across North Dakota? Thank the Standing Rock Tribe.
item.description: A tribally owned network of chargers will soon be complete, connecting reservations and bridging a gap in the Midwest.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey and Jaida Grey Eagle
item.media:credit: Jaida Grey Eagle for The New York Times

item.title: In Washington, Birds Are Giving ‘Yelp Reviews’ of Forest Restoration Work
item.description: A collective of land trusts, conservancies and tribes is capturing birdsong with audio gear and A.I. for clues about habitat health.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Meron Menghistab
item.media:credit: Meron Menghistab for The New York Times

item.title: Iowa City Made Its Buses Free. Traffic Cleared, and So Did the Air.
item.description: Ridership jumped, people cut back on driving and, over the summer, the city extended the program another year.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Annick Sjobakken
item.media:credit: Annick Sjobakken for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Lauds M.B.S. During White House Visit and Dismisses Khashoggi’s Killing
item.description: President Trump rejected a U.S. intelligence report finding that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman had ordered the murder of a journalist.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Trump and Mohammed bin Salman, the crown prince and prime minister of Saudi Arabia, in the Oval Office on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Said to Authorize C.I.A. Plans for Covert Action in Venezuela
item.description: The president has signed off on possible operations inside Venezuela but has also reopened back-channel communications with the government of President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The next phase of the Trump administration’s escalating pressure campaign on the government of President Nicolás Maduro could be sabotage or some sort of cyber, psychological or information operations.

item.title: Israeli Airstrike on Refugee Camp in Lebanon Kills at Least 13, Officials Say
item.description: It was one of the deadliest Israeli strikes on Lebanon since a cease-fire with Hezbollah went into effect about a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Members of the Lebanese Army gathered on Tuesday at the entrance of the Ain al-Hilweh refugee camp after an Israeli strike.

item.title: Frustrated With Your Home Insurer? Tell Us About It.
item.description: Help us track trends in the home insurance market by filling out this survey.
item.dc:creator: Mira Rojanasakul and Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Emily Kask for The New York Times

item.title: The Saudi crown prince receives an especially warm welcome at the White House.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: President Trump lavished praise on Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia during his visit to the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Investigating a Recycling Disaster
item.description: We went to Nigeria, where recycling plants are extracting lead for use in American and European car batteries — at a terrible human cost.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Environmentalists Sue to Stop Oil Lease Sales in the Gulf of Mexico
item.description: A Trump administration proposal to allow more exploration for oil and gas violates environmental laws, the groups said.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.category: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement
item.media:description: An oil operation in the Gulf of Mexico.

item.title: Khashoggi’s widow wants the U.S. to pressure Saudi Arabia to return his remains.
item.description: James Khashoggi, U.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Jamal and Hanan Elatr Khashoggi were married in 2018, a few months before Jamal was killed in Istanbul.

item.title: ‘Things Happen’: Trump Brushes Off the Murder of Khashoggi
item.description: A reporter asked Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman about the murder of the Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi. President Trump interjected.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:description: President Trump responds to a reporter’s question about the murder of the Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump wants a Saudi-Israel deal, but that’s not likely soon.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar
item.media:description: President Trump in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, this year. Mr. Trump has continued to argue that a diplomatic breakthrough is within reach.

item.title: Trump Team Calls Maduro a ‘Cartel’ Boss. That Word Doesn’t Mean What You Think.
item.description: Venezuelans coined a figure of speech for the phenomenon of generals corrupted by drug money: “Cartel de los Soles.” Then the United States started talking about it as a literal organization.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump Treasury Department officially labeled Cartel de los Soles a global terrorist entity in July.

item.title: For the Saudi crown prince, international criticism over the killing of Jamal Khashoggi has faded.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Jamal Khashoggi in Manama, Bahrain, in 2014.

item.title: Trump Family’s Business Ties to Saudi Arabia Raise Ethics Worries
item.description: President Trump will host Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Saudi Arabia’s de facto ruler, who oversees a major construction project that is in talks with the Trump family business.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: President Trump, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and Jerry Inzerillo at a model of the proposed Diriyah development during a state dinner in Saudi Arabia in May.

item.title: Cloudflare Outage Disrupts X, ChatGPT and Other Parts of the Internet
item.description: Services from Cloudflare, a software company, underpin thousands of websites, including X, Spotify and OpenAI. The company said a crash in a software system was to blame.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Cloudflare’s headquarters in San Francisco.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: The president is offering the crown prince fighter jets, a nuclear agreement and other deals as part of his efforts to collect investment and push forward on Middle East peace.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Vivian Nereim
item.category: Dar Al Arkan Real Estate Development Co

item.title: Greenpeace Faces an Unusual New Legal Attack From a Pipeline Giant
item.description: The company that won a huge verdict against Greenpeace earlier this year has asked a North Dakota court to block a countersuit in the Netherlands.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Protesting the Dakota Access Pipeline project near Cannonball, N.D., in September 2016. Earlier this year a court found Greenpeace liable for its role in demonstrations there.

item.title: How We Linked the Auto Industry to Lead Poisoning in Nigeria
item.description: Blood and soil testing confirmed the health consequences. Then we tracked individual shipments to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Will Fitzgibbon and Peter S. Goodman
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: True Metals lead smelting plant in Ogijo, Nigeria.

item.title: The Real Cost of U.S. Car Batteries
item.description: We followed the supply chain for batteries used in millions of U.S. cars to villages in Nigeria where people are being poisoned by lead. Peter S. Goodman, who covers economics and geopolitics for The Times, describes our yearlong investigation.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman, Will Fitzgibbon, Melanie Bencosme, Finbarr O’Reilly, Jon Miller, June Kim, Laura Salaberry and Carmen Abd Ali

item.title: Trump Gives Mixed Messages About Military Action Against Venezuela
item.description: President Trump said that he was open to talking with President Nicolás Maduro but that the United States has “to take care of Venezuela” as the U.S. builds a military force in the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office on Monday. Last month, Mr. Trump called off efforts to reach a diplomatic agreement with Venezuela, but the president has raised the possibility of renewed engagement.

item.title: Worker Error Is Faulted After Israeli-Born Canadian Hits Passport Snag
item.description: A student in Montreal, who was born in Kfar Saba, Israel, said she was initially told she could not list Israel as her birth country on her passport.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: U.N. Security Council Adopts Trump’s Peace Plan for Gaza
item.description: Russia and China abstained in the vote, which provides a legal mandate for the Trump administration’s vision of how to move past the cease-fire to rebuild the war-ravaged enclave after two years of war.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The American resolution passed in the U.N. Security Council on Monday with 13 votes in favor.

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Will Sell F-35s to Saudis, Despite Pentagon Concerns
item.description: The president told reporters in the Oval Office on Monday that he planned to sell the advanced fighter jets to Riyadh.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump and Melania Trump, the first lady, watch an F-35 fighter jet during a demonstration off the coast of Norfolk, Va., last month.

item.title: 2 Charged in Over 300 Thefts at Mausoleums in Toronto Area
item.description: The thefts took place during the daytime when the pair would enter mausoleums to swipe necklaces and other jewelry from remains, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz

item.title: Trump and the ‘Donroe Doctrine’
item.description: The president is claiming a special U.S. sphere of influence in the Western Hemisphere.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times

item.title: 25 Girls Abducted From School in Nigeria
item.description: The kidnapping echoed the abduction of the Chibok girls 11 years ago and came as U.S. officials pressed the country to address violence against Christians.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Ismail Auwal
item.media:description: The dormitories where gunmen kidnapped schoolchildren in Kebbi, Nigeria, on Monday.

item.title: Study Analyzes How Much ‘Macro’ Plastic Is Deadly to Sea Life
item.description: Scientists analyzed thousands of autopsies of seabirds, sea turtles and marine mammals and found that even small amounts of ingested plastic can be deadly.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:description: An autopsied Hawksbill sea turtle in a lab in the United Arab Emirates. Lying beside the turtle are items removed from its stomach, including a large amount of plastic.

item.title: Why Britain Is Embracing ‘Negative Nation Branding’
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer, trying to get a grip on a feverish immigration debate, is introducing a hard-line, contentious policy on refugees.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain walking out of 10 Downing Street on Monday. Some members of Mr. Starmer’s Labour Party object to Britain’s new restrictions on immigration.

item.title: Serbian Woman Ends Hunger Strike Against Government
item.description: Dijana Hrka became the face of protest after her son and 15 other people died in a railway station collapse in Serbia. Her hunger strike lasted 16 days.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Alisa Dogramadzieva
item.media:description: Dijana Hrka preparing to speak to the press outside Parliament on Monday about ending her hunger strike.

item.title: What Questions Do You Have About U.S. Immigration Policies?
item.description: “Ask a Correspondent” will take your questions to Hamed Aleaziz, our immigration reporter.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Trump Project in Maldives Opens More Doors for Cryptocurrency Investors
item.description: The Trump Organization and its Middle East development partner have announced a project in the Maldives that marries two of the family’s most successful moneymaking enterprises.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz and Eric Lipton
item.category: Dar Al Arkan Real Estate Development Co
item.media:description: Eric Trump, the executive vice president of the Trump Organization and the president’s son, looked over a real estate plan on another project involving the Dubai-based company Dar Global in Doha in April.

item.title: A Plan for Private Jet Taxes Would Fund Climate Measures
item.description: A small group of countries is aiming to impose a fee on private jets and premium commercial fares. The revenue would help nations adapt to warming.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: A private jet at the Farnborough International Airshow last year. Aviation accounts for roughly 4 percent of greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: Top U.N. Official Pushing to Get Aid Into Stricken Sudanese City
item.description: Paramilitaries accused of atrocities pledged to allow international aid and investigators into El Fasher, days after an airstrike hit a United Nations vehicle.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: A camp in Al Dabbah, Sudan, on Sunday. The newly established camp has received some of the thousands of people displaced by fighting in El Fasher.

item.title: Trump Administration Releases Thousands of Amelia Earhart Files
item.description: More than 4,000 documents related to Earhart were posted online, but scholars were not impressed. The release coincides with a period of intensified interest in the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein and his connection to the president.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: More than 4,600 pages of documents related to Amelia Earhart were released on Friday, including at least one photograph and a number of documents that were already available to the public.

item.title: Senator Accuses Kenya of Neglecting Children Trapped in Saudi Arabia
item.description: The comments, by a member of Kenya’s ruling party, represent a rebuke of President William Ruto’s government: “Heads must roll.”
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Iman Al-Dabbagh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abudy, an infant who was living on the street Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, with his Kenyan mother, Esther.

item.title: Polish Railway Explosion Was Sabotage, Prime Minister Says
item.description: Donald Tusk said unidentified saboteurs had tried to “blow up a train” on a route crucial for getting aid into Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Anatol Magdziarz
item.media:credit: Chancellery of the Prime Minister of Poland, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo released by the office of Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland on Monday shows Mr. Tusk and others at the site of an explosion on the tracks in Mika, Poland, between Warsaw and Lublin.

item.title: France Agrees to Sell Up to 100 Rafale Fighter Jets to Ukraine
item.description: Some in Ukraine criticized the 10-year timeline for the warplanes and other defense equipment, but France called it a long-term commitment to the country.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: François Bayrou, top left, then the prime minister of France, with a Rafale fighter aircraft in June. France said on Monday that it would sell up to 100 such jets to Ukraine.

item.title: Drawing Religion Minister’s Ire, Music Video is Pulled by Universal in Malaysia
item.description: The minister criticized the girl band Dolla for wearing revealing outfits in a clip for their hit “Question.” He also threatened criminal action.
item.dc:creator: Zunaira Saieed

item.title: Ukraine’s Cash Is Running Low, and Europe Has No Good Plan B
item.description: The European Union wants to finance Ukraine’s war efforts using a loan based on Russia’s frozen assets in Belgium. If that falls through, there’s no easy alternative.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial to fallen soldiers in Ukraine this month. The scale of the devastation from Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine continues to mount.

item.title: Man Who Rushed Ariana Grande in Singapore Gets 9 Days in Jail
item.description: He pleaded guilty to one charge of being a public nuisance.
item.dc:creator: Toh Ee Ming and Victor Mather
item.media:credit: The Straits Times/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Johnson Wen, in white, is seized by security after jumping a barricade and approaching Ariana Grande at a premiere.

item.title: More Than 40 Indian Pilgrims Are Killed in Bus Crash in Saudi Arabia
item.description: The passengers, who were participating in the Umrah pilgrimage, were traveling between the two holiest cities in Islam, authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Family members of the victims of a bus crash in Saudi Arabia mourned in Hyderabad, India, home to many of the passengers, on Monday.
